query: aging senescence epigenetic clock longevity hallmarks lifespan healthspan inflammaging proteostasis mTOR sirtuins rejuvenation senolytics autophagy

concepts.label: chronological age prediction
concepts.description: Estimation of a person's actual age from biological markers, particularly DNA methylation patterns.

concepts.label: DNA methylation
concepts.description: Chemical modification of cytosine bases in DNA that serves as an epigenetic marker correlated with age and cellular state.

concepts.label: biological age
concepts.description: Measure of physiological aging status derived from molecular markers, potentially differing from chronological age.

concepts.label: Epigenetic Correlation Drift
concepts.description: Temporal variation in the relationship between DNA methylation patterns and age across different life stages.

concepts.label: Heterogeneity Among CpGs
concepts.description: Variability in how individual CpG sites respond to aging and their predictive contributions across population subgroups.

concepts.label: CpG sites
concepts.description: Genomic locations where cytosine is followed by guanine, commonly subject to methylation and age-related changes.

concepts.label: similarity searching
concepts.description: Computational method to identify and group similar DNA methylation profiles based on distance or similarity metrics.

concepts.label: age group clustering
concepts.description: Partitioning of methylation profiles into groups corresponding to different life stages or age ranges.

concepts.label: Explainable Boosting Machines
concepts.description: Interpretable machine learning algorithm that combines boosting with inherent explainability for feature importance and interactions.

concepts.label: group-specific prediction
concepts.description: Machine learning approach that trains separate models for distinct population subgroups to improve accuracy and capture heterogeneity.

concepts.label: CpG interactions
concepts.description: Pairwise or higher-order joint effects between CpG methylation sites on age prediction.

concepts.label: aging rates
concepts.description: Rate of change in biological markers over time, potentially varying across age groups and individuals.

concepts.label: epigenetic clocks
concepts.description: Predictive models trained on methylation data to estimate biological age, used as reference benchmarks.

concepts.label: feature importance
concepts.description: Quantitative measure of how much individual features (CpG sites) contribute to model predictions.

concepts.label: iTARGET algorithm
concepts.description: Two-phase method combining age-group clustering via similarity search and group-specific EBM-based age prediction.

concepts.label: onset of senescence
concepts.description: The age at which the senescent process begins to manifest with measurable increases in mortality risk.

concepts.label: life expectancy
concepts.description: The average number of years an individual is expected to live, a key demographic measure of population longevity.

concepts.label: pace of senescence
concepts.description: The rate at which individuals accumulate age-related mortality risk; the speed at which the aging process unfolds.

concepts.label: period shocks
concepts.description: Transient, time-limited disturbances in mortality patterns caused by historical events affecting entire populations simultaneously.

concepts.label: biological baseline
concepts.description: The underlying intrinsic component of age-specific mortality risk attributable to fundamental biological aging processes.

concepts.label: long-term trend
concepts.description: A systematic directional change in mortality patterns or senescence pace occurring over extended time periods across generations.

concepts.label: cohort mortality data
concepts.description: Age-specific death rates tracked longitudinally for groups of individuals born in the same period, used to study aging patterns.

concepts.label: decomposition framework
concepts.description: A mathematical or statistical method that separates an observed phenomenon into distinct constituent components for analysis.

concepts.label: Vaupel hypothesis
concepts.description: The proposition that human longevity gains derive from delayed senescence onset rather than slowed pace of aging itself.

concepts.label: epigenetic landscape
concepts.description: Patterns of chemical modifications on histone tails that regulate gene expression and maintain cell identity.

concepts.label: histone modification
concepts.description: Chemical modifications (acetylation, deacetylation, methylation) on histone tail residues that alter chromatin structure and transcriptional activity.

concepts.label: sirtuin
concepts.description: NAD+-dependent histone deacetylase involved in DNA damage repair and stress response.

concepts.label: DNA double-strand break
concepts.description: Break in both strands of the DNA double helix, a critical form of genomic damage requiring rapid repair.

concepts.label: chromatin architecture
concepts.description: Three-dimensional organisation and folding of chromatin fiber into domains and topologically associating units.

concepts.label: long-range chromatin contact
concepts.description: Physical interactions between distant genomic regions mediated by chromatin looping and 3D structure.

concepts.label: stochastic model
concepts.description: Computational framework incorporating probabilistic transitions to simulate histone modification dynamics and chromatin behavior.

concepts.label: epigenetic erosion
concepts.description: Loss or destabilisation of normal histone modification patterns in response to stress or enzyme depletion.

concepts.label: enzyme relocalisation
concepts.description: Movement of histone-modifying enzymes from their normal distribution to specific genomic sites, such as DNA damage foci.

concepts.label: cell identity
concepts.description: Stable cell-type-specific transcriptional and phenotypic state maintained by epigenetic regulation.

concepts.label: tissue homeostasis
concepts.description: Maintenance of stable tissue structure and function through coordinated epigenetic and cellular processes.

concepts.label: genomic stress
concepts.description: Conditions such as DNA damage, replication fork collapse, or oxidative stress that threaten genomic integrity.

concepts.label: chromatin resilience
concepts.description: Capacity of chromatin structure to resist destabilisation of epigenetic patterns under stress conditions.

edges.evidence: DNA methylation patterns serve as primary input for accurate age prediction; the task is to estimate chronological age from these patterns.
ECD creates challenges for age prediction by reflecting dynamic and non-stationary relationships between methylation and age.
HAC complicates prediction as different CpG sites contribute heterogeneously across life stages and individuals.
CpG sites are the genomic locations where methylation modifications occur.
The first phase employs similarity searching to cluster methylation profiles by age group.
Age group clustering constitutes the first phase of the two-phase iTARGET algorithm.
The second phase uses EBM for precise, group-specific prediction of age.
Group-specific EBM prediction constitutes the second phase of the two-phase iTARGET algorithm.
iTARGET is a novel two-phase algorithm designed to improve prediction accuracy for chronological age from methylation.
The group-specific approach of iTARGET is designed to handle heterogeneity among CpGs across different populations.
Age-group clustering in iTARGET addresses ECD by capturing life-stage-specific methylation-age relationships.
EBM provides inherent explainability to reveal key age-related CpG sites and their importance.
Key age-related CpG sites are identified through feature importance measures from the EBM model.
EBM identifies pairwise interactions between CpG sites as part of its interpretable analysis.
The method detects age-specific changes in aging rates through its group-specific prediction approach.
Accurate chronological age prediction from methylation advances biological age estimation.
Experimental results show that iTARGET outperforms traditional epigenetic clocks and machine learning models.
Human aging is marked by steady rise in risk of dying with age; this process determines life expectancy gains.
The pace of senescence is a core attribute describing how quickly the aging process unfolds.
Vaupel hypothesizes that gains in longevity come from delayed onset of senescence rather than its slowing down.
Hypothesis proposes that the pace at which individuals age may be constant, with longevity gains from delayed onset.
New framework decomposes the pace of senescence into three components: biological baseline, long-term trend, and cumulative period shocks.
Biological baseline is one of three decomposed components of the pace of senescence.
Long-term trend is one of three decomposed components of the pace of senescence.
Cumulative impact of period shocks is one of three decomposed components of the pace of senescence.
Framework applied to cohort mortality data from 12 countries to test Vaupel's hypothesis.
Once period shocks are accounted for, there is no statistical evidence of a long-term trend in pace of senescence.
Variations in mortality patterns are consistent with echoes of shared historical events affecting populations.
Epigenetic landscapes are represented by patterns of chemical modifications on histone tails.
Epigenetic landscapes are essential for maintaining cell identity and tissue homeostasis.
Epigenetic landscapes are essential for maintaining cell identity and tissue homeostasis.
Epigenetic landscapes are shaped by the three-dimensional organisation of chromatin.
Sirtuins are histone deacetylases that modify histone tails via deacetylation.
Sirtuin relocalisation to DSB sites leads to epigenetic erosion in response to genomic stress.
Sirtuin relocalisation to DSB sites leads to epigenetic erosion.
Sirtuins are histone deacetylases involved in DSB repair.
Chromatin regions with large domains of long-range contacts are more resilient to epigenetic destabilisation.
A stochastic model of histone modification dynamics was used to investigate epigenetic pattern destabilisation.
The stochastic model was integrated with chromatin architecture to investigate histone modification dynamics.
Response to genomic stress such as DNA double-strand breaks destabilises epigenetic patterns.
The resulting landscape depends on chromatin geometry; regions with large long-range contact domains are more resilient.
